messages.content:
You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Output:
{
  "citations": [
    {
      "ref_index": 38,
      "titles": [
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "A performance evaluation of federated learning algorithms",
        "Distributed machine learning: A survey",
        "Communication protocols for distributed learning",
        "Scalable federated learning systems",
        "Efficient distributed training algorithms",
        "Large-scale distributed learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]38 appears in the context of 'massively distributed networks' for federated learning, so it likely refers to foundational papers on federated learning systems, distributed training, and communication-efficient methods in distributed networks."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 5,
      "titles": [
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Ensemble methods in machine learning",
        "Random forests for classification",
        "Bootstrap methods and their application",
        "Combining multiple classifiers",
        "Large-scale machine learning systems",
        "Distributed ensemble methods",
        "Scalable classification algorithms",
        "Massive data processing techniques",
        "High-performance machine learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]5 appears in the context of 'at a large scale', suggesting it refers to papers on scaling machine learning methods, ensemble techniques, or methods that can handle large-scale data and distributed settings."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 30,
      "titles": [
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Fair machine learning: A survey",
        "Bias in machine learning systems",
        "Addressing fairness in AI systems",
        "Fair representation learning",
        "Heterogeneous data handling methods",
        "Multi-source learning algorithms",
        "Cross-domain representation learning",
        "Fair learning from diverse data",
        "Bias mitigation in heterogeneous datasets"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]30 appears in the context of 'heterogeneous data' and 'fair representation learning', indicating it likely refers to papers on heterogenous data handling, bias mitigation, and learning representations that are fair across different data distributions."
    }
  ]
}

CRITICAL: Return ONLY the JSON object. Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not use markdown formatting. Ensure all quotes and special characters are properly escaped.

IMPORTANT NOTES ON REASONING:
- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Limitations of Sums of Bounded Read Formulas

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
In this section, we present necessary definitions and notations. For more details, reader is referred to excellent surveys by Shpilka and YehudayoffÂ  and by Saptharishi et al.Â . Let X={x1,â€¦,xn}ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›X=\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\} be a set of variables.
An arithmetic circuit Cğ¶C over a field ğ”½ğ”½\mathbb{F} with input Xğ‘‹X is a directed acyclic graph (DAG) where the nodes have in-degree zero or two. The nodes of in-degree zero are called input gates and are labeled by elements from Xâˆªğ”½ğ‘‹ğ”½X\cup\mathbb{F}. Non-input gates of Cğ¶C are called internal gates and are labeled from {+,tâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹eâ€‹s}ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘ \{+,times\}. Nodes of out degree zero are called output gates. Typically, a circuit has a single output gate. Every gate vğ‘£v in Cğ¶C naturally computes a polynomial fvâˆˆğ”½â€‹[X]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘£ğ”½delimited-[]ğ‘‹f_{v}\in\mathbb{F}[X]. The polynomial computed by Cğ¶C is the polynomial represented at its output gate.
The size of a circuit denoted by sizeâ€‹(C)sizeğ¶\text{size}(C), is the number of gates in it, and depth is the length of the longest root to leaf path in Cğ¶C, denoted by depthâ€‹(C)depthğ¶\text{depth}(C). An arithmetic formula is a circuit where the underlying undirected graph is a tree. For a gate vğ‘£v in Cğ¶C, let ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹â€‹(v)ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹ğ‘£{\sf var}(v) denote the set of all variables that appear as leaf labels in the sub-circuit rooted at vğ‘£v. Multilinear polynomials are polynomials such that in every monomial, the degree of a variable is either 00 or 111. Multilinear circuits, where every gate in the circuit computes a multilinear polynomial, are natural models of computation for multilinear polynomials. A circuit Cğ¶C is said to be syntactic multilinear if for every product gate v=v1Ã—v2ğ‘£subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2v=v_{1}\times v_{2} in Cğ¶C, we have ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹â€‹(v1)âˆ©ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹â€‹(v2)=âˆ…ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹subscriptğ‘£1ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹subscriptğ‘£2{\sf var}(v_{1})\cap{\sf var}(v_{2})=\emptyset. By definition, a syntactic multilinear circuit is also multilinear and computes a multilinear polynomial. An arithmetic formula Fğ¹F is said to be a read-once formula (ROF in short) if every input variable in Xğ‘‹X labels at most one input gate in Fğ¹F. Algebraic branching program (ABP in short) is a model of computation of polynomials defined as analogous to the branching program model of computation for Boolean functions. An ABP Pğ‘ƒP is a layered DAG with layers L0,â€¦,Lmsubscriptğ¿0â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘šL_{0},\ldots,L_{m} such L0={s}subscriptğ¿0ğ‘ L_{0}=\{s\} and Lm={t}subscriptğ¿ğ‘šğ‘¡L_{m}=\{t\} where sğ‘ s is the start node and tğ‘¡t is the terminal node.
Each edge is labeled by an element in Xâˆªğ”½ğ‘‹ğ”½X\cup\mathbb{F}. The output of the ABP Pğ‘ƒP is the polynomial p=âˆ‘Ïâ€‹is aÂ sÂ toÂ tÂ pathğ—ğ—â€‹(Ï)ğ‘subscriptğœŒis aÂ sÂ toÂ tÂ pathğ—ğ—ğœŒp=\sum_{\rho\text{is a $s$ to $t$ path}}{\sf wt}(\rho), where ğ—ğ—â€‹(Ï)ğ—ğ—ğœŒ{\sf wt}(\rho) is the product of edge labels in the path ÏğœŒ\rho. Further, for any two nodes uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v let [u,v]Psubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘ƒ[u,v]_{P} denote the polynomial computed by the subprogram Puâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¢ğ‘£P_{uv} of Pğ‘ƒP with uğ‘¢u as the start node and vğ‘£v as the terminal node. Let Xuâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¢ğ‘£X_{uv} denote the set of variables that appear as edge labels in the subprogram Puâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¢ğ‘£P_{uv}. The size of an ABP Pğ‘ƒP, denoted by sizeâ€‹(P)sizeğ‘ƒ\text{size}(P) is the number of nodes in Pğ‘ƒP. In a syntactic multilinear ABP (smABP), every sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t path reads any input variables at most once. An ABP is oblivious if every layer reads at most one variable. A read-once oblivious ABP (ROABP) is an oblivious syntactic multilinear ABP where every variable can appear in at most one variable i.e., for every iğ‘–i, there is at most one layer jisubscriptğ‘—ğ‘–j_{i} such that xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} occurs as a label on the edges from Ljisubscriptğ¿subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–L_{j_{i}} to Lji+1subscriptğ¿subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–1L_{j_{i}+1}. An interval on the set {1,â€¦,n}1â€¦ğ‘›\{1,\ldots,n\} with end-points i,jâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›i,j\in[n], can be defined as I=[i,j],i<jformulae-sequenceğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—I=[i,j],\leavevmode\nobreak\ i<j, where I={â„“âˆ£i,jâˆˆ[n],iâ‰¤â„“â‰¤j}ğ¼conditional-setâ„“formulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘–â„“ğ‘—I=\{\ell\mid i,j\in[n],i\leq\ell\leq j\}. An interval of variables Xiâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘—X_{ij} is defined such that Xiâ€‹jâŠ†{xâ„“âˆ£â„“âˆˆI,I=[i,j]}subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘—conditional-setsubscriptğ‘¥â„“formulae-sequenceâ„“ğ¼ğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—X_{ij}\subseteq\{x_{\ell}\mid\ell\in I,\leavevmode\nobreak\ I=[i,j]\}, where Iğ¼I is an interval on the set {1,â€¦,n}1â€¦ğ‘›\{1,\dots,n\}. For an ordering Ï€âˆˆSnğœ‹subscriptğ‘†ğ‘›\pi\in S_{n}, we define a Ï€ğœ‹\pi-interval of variables, Xiâ€‹jâŠ†{xÏ€â€‹(i),xÏ€â€‹(i+1),â€¦,xÏ€â€‹(j)}subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘—X_{ij}\subseteq\{x_{\pi(i)},x_{\pi(i+1)},\ldots,x_{\pi(j)}\}.
InÂ [ref]4, Arvind and Raja defined a sub-class of syntactically multilinear ABPs known as interval ABPs and proved lower bounds against the same. Later,  defined a further restricted version of interval ABPs, denoted by strict-interval ABPs, defined as follows. ()
A strict interval ABP Pğ‘ƒP is a syntactically multilinear ABP where we have the following: For any pair of nodes uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v in Pğ‘ƒP, the indices of variables occurring in the sub-program [u,v]Psubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘ƒ[u,v]_{P} is contained in some Ï€ğœ‹\pi-interval Iuâ€‹vsubscriptğ¼ğ‘¢ğ‘£I_{uv} called the associated interval of [u,v]Psubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘ƒ[u,v]_{P}; and for any pairs of sub-programs of the form [u,v]P,[v,w]Psubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¤ğ‘ƒ[u,v]_{P},\leavevmode\nobreak\ [v,w]_{P}, the associatedÏ€ğœ‹\pi-intervals of variables are disjoint,
i.e., Iuâ€‹vâˆ©Ivâ€‹w=âˆ…subscriptğ¼ğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptğ¼ğ‘£ğ‘¤I_{uv}\cap I_{vw}=\emptyset. It may be noted that in a strict interval ABP, intervals associated with each sub-program need not be unique. We assume that the intervals associated are largest intervals with respect to set inclusion such that condition 2 in the definition above is satisfied. We need the notion of partial derivative matrices introduced by RazÂ  and NisanÂ [ref]26 as primary measure of complexity for multilinear polynomials. The partial derivative matrix of a polynomial fâˆˆğ•ğ‘“ğ•f\in\mathbb{X} defined based on a partition Ï†:Xâ†’YâˆªZ:ğœ‘â†’ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘\varphi:X\to Y\cup Z of the Xğ‘‹X into two parts. We follow the definition inÂ : (RazÂ ) Let Ï†:Xâ†’YâˆªZ:ğœ‘â†’ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘\varphi:X\to Y\cup Z be a partition of the input variables in two parts. Let â„³Ysubscriptâ„³ğ‘Œ\mathcal{M}_{Y}, â„³Zsubscriptâ„³ğ‘\mathcal{M}_{Z} be the sets of all possible multilinear monomials in the variables in Yğ‘ŒY and Zğ‘Z respectively. Then we construct the partial derivative matrix MfÏ†subscriptğ‘€superscriptğ‘“ğœ‘M_{f^{\varphi}} for a multilinear polynomial fğ‘“f under the partition Ï†ğœ‘\varphi such that the rows of the matrix are indexed by monomials miâˆˆâ„³Ysubscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptâ„³ğ‘Œm_{i}\in\mathcal{M}_{Y}, the columns by monomials sjâˆˆâ„³Zsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—subscriptâ„³ğ‘s_{j}\in\mathcal{M}_{Z} and entry MfÏ†â€‹(i,j)=ciâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘€superscriptğ‘“ğœ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—M_{f^{\varphi}}(i,j)=c_{ij}, ciâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—c_{ij} being the coefficient of the monomial miâ‹…sjâ‹…subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—m_{i}\cdot s_{j} in fğ‘“f. We denote by ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(f)subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘ğ‘“{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(f) the rank of the matrix MfÏ†subscriptğ‘€superscriptğ‘“ğœ‘M_{f^{\varphi}}. We call Ï†ğœ‘\varphi an equi-partition when |X|=nğ‘‹ğ‘›|X|=n, nğ‘›n even and |Y|=|Z|=n/2ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘›2|Y|=|Z|=n/2. RazÂ  showed the following fundamental property of ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘{\sf rank}_{\varphi}: Let gğ‘”g and hâ„h be multilinear polynomials in ğ”½â€‹[X]ğ”½delimited-[]ğ‘‹\mathbb{F}[X]. Then, âˆ€Ï†:Xâ†’YâˆªZ:for-allğœ‘â†’ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘\forall\varphi:X\to Y\cup Z, we have the following. ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(g+h)â‰¤ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(g)+ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(h)subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘ğ‘”â„subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘ğ‘”subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘â„{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(g+h)\leq{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(g)+{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(h), and ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(gâ€‹h)â‰¤ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(g)Ã—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(h)subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘ğ‘”â„subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘ğ‘”subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘â„{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(gh)\leq{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(g)\times{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(h), In both the cases, equality holds when ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹â€‹(g)âˆ©ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹â€‹(h)=âˆ…ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹ğ‘”ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹â„{\sf var}(g)\cap{\sf var}(h)=\emptyset. Polynomials that exhibit maximum rank ofthe partial derivative matrix under all or a large fraction of equi-partitions can be thought of as high complexity or hard polynomials. We need two such families found in the literature. Raz and YehudayoffÂ  defined a multilinear in \VP\VP\VP. To define this polynomial we denote an interval {aâˆ£iâ‰¤aâ‰¤j,aâˆˆâ„•},i,jâˆˆâ„•conditional-setğ‘formulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘â„•ğ‘–ğ‘—â„•\{a\mid i\leq a\leq j,a\in\mathbb{N}\},\leavevmode\nobreak\ i,j\in\mathbb{N} by [i,j]ğ‘–ğ‘—[i,j], and consider the sets of variables X={x1,â€¦,x2â€‹n}ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘›X=\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{2n}\}, W={wi,â„“,j}i,â„“,jâˆˆ[2â€‹n]ğ‘Šsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â„“ğ‘—ğ‘–â„“ğ‘—delimited-[]2ğ‘›W=\{w_{i,\ell,j}\}_{i,\ell,j\in[2n]}. We denote it as the Raz-Yehudayoff polynomial and define it as follows. Let us consider fiâ€‹jâˆˆğ”½â€‹[X,W]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ”½ğ‘‹ğ‘Šf_{ij}\in\mathbb{F}[X,W] defined over the interval [i,j]ğ‘–ğ‘—[i,j].
For iâ‰¤jğ‘–ğ‘—i\leq j, the polynomial fiâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘—f_{ij} is defined inductively as follows.
If jâˆ’i=0ğ‘—ğ‘–0j-i=0, then fiâ€‹j=0subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘—0f_{ij}=0. For |jâˆ’i|>0ğ‘—ğ‘–0|j-i|>0, where we assume without loss of generality, lengths of [i,â„“],[â„“+1,j]ğ‘–â„“â„“1ğ‘—[i,\ell],\leavevmode\nobreak\ [\ell+1,j] are even and smaller than [i,j]ğ‘–ğ‘—[i,j]. We define f1,2â€‹nsubscriptğ‘“12ğ‘›f_{1,2n} as the Raz-Yehudayoff polynomial fğ–±ğ–¸subscriptğ‘“ğ–±ğ–¸f_{{\sf RY}}. Note that, fğ–±ğ–¸subscriptğ‘“ğ–±ğ–¸f_{\sf RY} can be defined over any subset Xâ€²âŠ†Xsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘‹X^{\prime}\subseteq X such that |Xâ€²|superscriptğ‘‹â€²|X^{\prime}| is even, by considering the induced ordering of variables in Xâ€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²X^{\prime} and considering intervals accordingly. We denote this polynomial as fğ–±ğ–¸â€‹(Xâ€²)subscriptğ‘“ğ–±ğ–¸superscriptğ‘‹â€²f_{\sf RY}(X^{\prime}) for Xâ€²âŠ†Xsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘‹X^{\prime}\subseteq X.
Raz and Yehudayoff showed:  ()
Let ğ”¾=ğ”½â€‹(W)ğ”¾ğ”½ğ‘Š\mathbb{G}=\mathbb{F}(W) be the field of rational functions over the field ğ”½ğ”½\mathbb{F} and the set of variables Wğ‘ŠW. Then for every equi-partition Ï†:Xâ†’YâˆªZ:ğœ‘â†’ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘\varphi:X\to Y\cup Z, ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(fğ–±ğ–¸)=2n/2subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ–±ğ–¸superscript2ğ‘›2{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(f_{{\sf RY}})=2^{n/2}. Dvir et al.Â  defined a polynomial that is hard i.e., full rank with respect to a special class of partitions called arc-partitions. Suppose X={x0,â€¦,xnâˆ’1}ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›1X=\{x_{0},\ldots,x_{n-1}\} be identified with the set V={0,â€¦,nâˆ’1}ğ‘‰0â€¦ğ‘›1V=\{0,\ldots,n-1\}. For i,jâˆˆVğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‰i,j\in V, the set [i,j]={i,(i+1)modn,(i+2)modn,â€¦,j}ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–moduloğ‘–1ğ‘›moduloğ‘–2ğ‘›â€¦ğ‘—[i,j]=\{i,(i+1)\mod n,(i+2)\mod n,\ldots,j\} is called the arc from iğ‘–i to jğ‘—j.
An arc pairing is a distribution on the set of all pairings (i.e., perfect matchings) on Vğ‘‰V obtained in n/2ğ‘›2n/2 steps as follows.
Assuming a pairing (P1,â€¦,Pt)subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡(P_{1},\ldots,P_{t}) constructed in t<n/2ğ‘¡ğ‘›2t<n/2 steps, where P1=(0,1)subscriptğ‘ƒ101P_{1}=(0,1), [Lt,Rt]subscriptğ¿ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡[L_{t},R_{t}] is the interval spanned by âˆªiâˆˆ[t]Pisubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–\cup_{i\in[t]}P_{i} and the random pair Pt+1subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡1P_{t+1} is constructed such that and therefore, [Lt+1,Rt+1]=[Lt,Rt]âˆªPt+1subscriptğ¿ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1subscriptğ¿ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¡1[L_{t+1},R_{t+1}]=[L_{t},R_{t}]\cup P_{t+1}. Given a pairing ğ’«={P1,â€¦,Pn/2}ğ’«subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›2{\cal P}=\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{n/2}\} of Vğ‘‰V, there are exactly 2n/2superscript2ğ‘›22^{n/2} partitions of Xğ‘‹X, by assigning Ï†â€‹(xi)âˆˆYğœ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘Œ\varphi(x_{i})\in Y and Ï†â€‹(xj)âˆˆZğœ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘\varphi(x_{j})\in Z or Ï†â€‹(xi)âˆˆZğœ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘\varphi(x_{i})\in Z and Ï†â€‹(xj)âˆˆYğœ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘Œ\varphi(x_{j})\in Y independently for each pair (i,j)âˆˆğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ’«(i,j)\in{\cal P}. An arc partition is a distribution on all partitions obtained by sampling an arc pairing as defined above and sampling a partition corresponding to the pairing uniformly at random. We denote this distribution on partitions by ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\mathcal{D}}. For a pairing ğ’«={P1,â€¦,Pn/2}ğ’«subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›2{\cal P}=\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{n/2}\} let Mğ’«subscriptğ‘€ğ’«M_{{\cal P}} be the degree n/2ğ‘›2n/2 polynomial âˆi=1n/2(xâ„“i+xri)superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘¥subscriptâ„“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–\prod_{i=1}^{n/2}(x_{\ell_{i}}+x_{r_{i}}) where Pi=(â„“i,ri)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptâ„“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–P_{i}=(\ell_{i},r_{i}). Dvir et al.Â  defined the arc full rank polynomial f^=âˆ‘ğ’«âˆˆğ’ŸÎ»ğ’«â€‹Mğ’«^ğ‘“subscriptğ’«ğ’Ÿsubscriptğœ†ğ’«subscriptğ‘€ğ’«\widehat{f}=\sum_{{\cal P}\in{\cal D}}\lambda_{{\cal P}}M_{{\cal P}}, where Î»ğ’«subscriptğœ†ğ’«\lambda_{\cal P} is a formal variable. Dvir et al.Â  showed: 

The polynomial f^^ğ‘“\widehat{f} can be computed by a polynomial size smABP and for every Ï†âˆˆğ’Ÿğœ‘ğ’Ÿ\varphi\in{\cal D},
ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„Ï†â€‹(f^)=2n/2subscriptğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—„ğœ‘^ğ‘“superscript2ğ‘›2{\sf rank}_{\varphi}(\widehat{f})=2^{n/2} over a suitable field extension ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G} of ğ”½ğ”½\mathbb{F}. Now that we are familiar with most of the definitions required for an understanding of the results in this paper, we proceed to discuss our results.

{retrieved_text}
